conclusion: The v-t graph shows how the velocity of each car changes over time.
The area under each curve represents the displacement of the car during the time interval.
Average velocity is total displacement divided by total time.
Car A starts at a higher velocity v2 and decreases to v1 at time t1.
Car B starts at a lower velocity v1 and increases to v2 at time t1.
The displacement is the area under the velocity-time curve.
Car A's area under the curve is a trapezoid with bases v2 and v1, and height t1.
Car B's area under the curve is a trapezoid with the same bases v2 and v1, and height t1.
Since both cars start and end at the same velocities over the same time interval, the areas under both curves are equal.
The displacements of Car A and Car B are the same.
Since the displacements are equal and the time interval t1 is the same for both cars, their average velocities must also be equal.
The average velocities of Car A and Car B from t = 0 to t = t1 are the same.
